title: 109_hr2066
content: The "General Services Administration Modernization Act" may be cited as the short title. Section 303 of title 40, United States Code, is amended to establish the Federal Acquisition Service. The General Services Administration Modernization Act establishes the Federal Acquisition Service within the General Services Administration. The Commissioner of the Federal Acquisition Service is appointed by the Administrator of General Services and is responsible for functions related to the Acquisition Services Fund. Regional Executives may be appointed to carry out specific tasks within the Federal Acquisition Service. The Federal Acquisition Service, under the General Services Administration Modernization Act, allows for the appointment of Regional Executives to carry out specific functions as deemed appropriate by the Administrator. The Federal Acquisition Service allows for the appointment of Regional Executives to carry out specific functions. The Federal Acquisition Service amends the Executive Schedule Compensation by changing references from the Federal Supply Service to the Federal Acquisition Service. This includes updating mentions of the Commissioner of the Federal Supply Service to the Commissioner of the Federal Acquisition Service. The Federal Acquisition Service amends the Executive Schedule Compensation by changing references from the Federal Supply Service to the Federal Acquisition Service, including updating mentions of the Commissioner. SEC. 3. ACQUISITION SERVICES FUND. The General Supply Fund and Information Technology Fund in the Treasury are abolished. Capital assets and balances from these funds will be transferred to the Acquisition Services Fund. Liabilities and obligations of the abolished funds will be assumed by the Acquisition Services Fund. The Acquisition Services Fund under section 321 of title 40, United States Code, will continue to exist. The Acquisition Services Fund under section 321 of title 40, United States Code, is a special fund in the Treasury. It is composed of authorized transfers, reimbursements, advances, refunds, and proceeds from disposal of surplus property. The Fund also includes receipts for loss or damage to property and fees charged by agencies. The Administrator is responsible for managing the Fund's cost and capital requirements. The Administrator determines the cost and capital requirements of the Acquisition Services Fund annually in consultation with the Chief Financial Officer of the General Services Administration. Rates for services provided through the Fund are established by the Administrator. Fees collected under section 313 may be deposited into the Fund for its purposes. In subsection (f), amendments are made to Section 321(d)(2)(A) of the title regarding payment for property and services related to information technology. Clause (v) now includes the cost of personal services directly involved in providing information technology. Following the close of each fiscal year, any uncommitted balance of funds in the Fund shall be transferred to the general fund of the Treasury as miscellaneous receipts. Section 322 of the title is repealed, and the heading for section 321 is amended. The Acquisition Services Fund under section 321 is amended, with section 322 repealed. Section 573 of title amended to replace "General Supply Fund" with "Acquisition Services Fund". Section 604(b) and Section 605 also amended accordingly. Section 573 of title is amended to replace "General Supply Fund" with "Acquisition Services Fund". SEC. 4. PROVISIONS RELATING TO ACQUISITION PERSONNEL. Section 37 of the Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act is amended to allow reemployment of individuals receiving an annuity from the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund in acquisition-related positions without discontinuing their annuity. The amendment allows reemployment of annuitants from the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund in acquisition-related positions without terminating their annuity. The criteria for exercising this authority include unique qualifications, difficulty in recruitment, or temporary emergency hiring needs. The Administrator must report annually to specific committees. The amendment allows reemployment of annuitants in acquisition-related positions without ending their annuity. The authority expires on December 31, 2011. SEC. 5 amends Section 549(c)(3)(B) of title 40, United States Code, to include historic light stations for disposal of federal surplus property. SEC. 6 states that the Act and its amendments will take effect 60 days after enactment.
